Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @PTYX the evil code was never on Github, it was an npm package. most npm packages have their source code on github, but released versions of npm packages do not need to correlate to code on Github. This is a big reason why you cannot use the next version of a dependency blindly. Every time you upgrade a dependency version, you must read it (and all it's dependencies) to make sure it's not malware.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but how to do that if binary and github source dont match?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for thousands of modules??

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the iguana approach of writing everything from scratch (other than the actual crypto signing and hashing) seems to be needed, regardless of language

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and for the libs i did use, i imported all the source into my tree, so nothing changes on me

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: many thought i was crazy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: The nodeJS system changes so fast and basic things require so many thousands of sub-dependencies. Nothing is designed to be maintained for years, it's all constantly changing. It's a perfect place for malware, like a busy airport with people from all over the world passing you by in all directions constantly. There is no easy way to see somebody that looks out of place,  it's an immense amount of work. Some people say they like JS enough to want to do that, but no thanks from me.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a language independent concept, this usage of libraries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but yes, node.js seems to force relying on a massive number of libraries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless you go out of your way

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: and said libraries, if not religously kept current and updated, will break your program, site, etc.

Author: LocoMB#8593
Content: not sure if python ever had such rampant dependency escalation ... packet structures much flatter and more robust

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes if you dont update you leave your self open to known exploits

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you update and you can get exploited unless you are extremely diligent, all the time

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: it's a hamster wheel. the first troubleshooting step for most is an npm update when something stops working.

Author: LocoMB#8593
Content: I asked over at the IOTA discord- they paid a specialized outfit beaucoup bucks to do what is apparently called a 'manual audit'

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which works until they mess up, or hire an employee that is a hacker

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we all need to really increase the level of scrutiny across the board

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
i got the refund processor coded and it will be sending out the first 90 refunds over the next hour or so. about half the claims for less than 777 KMD have properly sent the special tx 2) to the secure refund address. this is approx 10% of the affected users, so not a bad start. assuming there are no issues, the rest can be processed as soon as the proper claims are made with a matching send from the old address to the new secure address.

by the way, the refund processor is 500 lines of C code
